    Members are aware that my Ministry is placing great emphasis on health education. We had a very successful year in 1976 when we conducted a mass campaign against six diseases.      Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question. Could the Hon. Minister tell us some definite programmes to prevent the three leading causes of deaths in Singapore? So far, he has been rather hazy.

     Dr Toh Chin Chye: Sir, I do not know whether the Member for Potong Pasir is a vegetarian.

     An hon. Member: He is not!

     Dr Toh Chin Chye: If he is a vegetarian, then probably he will not have to worry about cholesterol and ischaemic heart disease. As far as cancer is concerned, there are many factors involved in producing cancer, but nobody really knows the reason why cancer

Column: 730

is induced. There is no cure for cancer. All that we can do is to take preventive measures. For example, there is a correlation between smoking and lung cancer. So obviously if Members of the House do not wish to catch cancer, they should not smoke. The other alternative is to urge the Minister for Finance to raise the tax on cigarettes. NOTIFIABLE INDUSTRIAL DISEASES
(Number of, and compensation paid)


    2. Mr Ivan Baptist asked the Minister for Labour (i) the monthly breakdown figures for each of the notifiable industrial diseases

Column: 731

confirmed in 1977 and the first two months of 1978; and (ii) the monthly breakdown figures of the quantum of compensation paid out for each of those industrial diseases.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, 769 cases of industrial diseases were notified and confirmed under the Factories Act during the period January 1977 to February 1978. Of this total, the highest number of 554 was in respect of noise-induced deafness. This high number is largely due to the continuing mobile audio-metric screening carried out by the Industrial Health Department under the Hearing Conservation Programme which was initiated in May 1976. Industrial Dermatitis accounted for 182 cases, followed by 24 cases of Compressed Air Illness. There were seven cases of Silicosis and one case each of Asbestosis and Lead Poisoning.

    The breakdown of cases confirmed by month and type of industrial disease for the period January 1977 to February 1978 is given in Table I of the Appendix (Cols. 825 - 826) which has been circulated to all Members. PURCHASE OF RESIDENTIAL PROPERTIES
BY PERMANENT RESIDENTS
(Relaxation of policy)


    4. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Law, the Environment and Science and Technology whether and to what extent the policy concerning the purchase of residential properties by permanent residents has been relaxed.

     The Minister for Law, the Environment and Science and Technology (Mr E.W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, as from 11th September, 1973, only citizens of Singapore have been allowed to purchase residential properties without any restriction. All others, including permanent residents, have been

Column: 733

required to obtain the written approval of Government to purchase residential property or any vacant land other than that zoned "Industrial-commercial". Approval depends on the economic contribution such persons or applicants make to Singapore.

    With effect from 10th January, 1975, this policy was relaxed and non-citizens were allowed to purchase flats or apartments in buildings of not less than six Storeys, including the ground floor. As from 3rd September, 1976, there was a further relaxation in that non-citizens were allowed free purchase of units in approved condominiums as well. Furthermore, where previously approvals were not considered in respect of residential houses on land exceeding 4,000 sq. ft., such applications in respect of land areas of not more than 15,000 sq. ft. are now favourably considered.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Hon. Minister inform the House how many applications for purchase of residential properties by permanent residents have been received, and how many have been approved since the operation of this law?

     Mr Barker: Sir, as at the end of last month, the total number of applications received from non-citizens amounted to 1,758. Of these, 423 applications were either withdrawn or settled upon clarification. 855 applicants obtained approval, of whom 572 were permanent residents and 283 were other non-citizens. 274 applications were not approved and there remain a number of 206 cases which are still being processed.

DRUG PUSHERS AND ADDICTS IN THE
JALAN KOLAM AYER QUARTERS AREA
(Particulars)


    5. Mr Ivan Baptist asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education (a) what surveillance work is being done in the Jalan Kolam Ayer Quarters area which is troubled by drug pushers and addicts especially late at

Column: 734

nights; and (b) how many drug pushers and addicts have been arrested in this area during the last 14 months.

     The Minister for Home Affairs and Education (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Central Narcotics Bureau and the Police are generally aware of the areas where drug pushing and drug abuse activities take place. Surveillance is carried out in these areas and when sufficient evidence has been gathered, enforcement action is taken against those involved. In addition, Divisional Police also carry out routine patrols in these areas. The Jalan Kolam Ayer Quarters area is one of them. However, for obvious reasons, I cannot disclose what sort of surveillance work is being carried out.

    During the past 14 months, 130 persons were arrested in the Jalan Kolam Ayer Quarters area on suspicion of having committed various drug offences. Of these, five were drug traffickers. Two of the traffickers were prosecuted and the other three were dealt with under the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Act. Sixteen persons were also prosecuted for other drug offences. Fifty-eight addicts were sent for compulsory treatment and rehabilitation at the Drug Rehabilitation Centres. The rest were released after investigation.

ELECTRONICS INDUSTRY IN SINGAPORE


    6. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Finance whether he is aware that in Singapore there are very few electronic component factories to support the electronics assembly factories; and if he has any plans to encourage the setting up of electronic component factories or plants so as to lessen dependence upon imported electronic components and ensure the availability of supply.

     The Senior Minister of State for Finance (Mr Goh Chok Tong) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are in fact

Column: 735

more companies in Singapore manufacturing electronic components than assembling electronic finished products. Out of about 125 electronics manufacturing companies, there are about 65 producing electronic components. Similarly, in dollar value, output of electronic components exceeds output of electronic finished products. The latest available detailed figures from the Statistics Department show that in 1976 the total output of electronic products and components amounted to about $1.9 billion and, out of this, more than $1 billion was output of electronic components.

    For a transistor radio, all the electronic components, except one, are manufactured in Singapore. The remaining component, the ferrite antenna bar, is likely to be manufactured locally by next year. Similarly, the majority of components for television sets, tape-recorders, electronic calculators and electronic watches are manufactured locally.

    It has always been one of the major objectives of the Economic Development Board to encourage further integration of the electronics industry. Arising from encouragement by the Economic Development Board, there are plans by more companies to manufacture components in Singapore, especially key components such as television tuners and picture tubes for television sets; cassette mechanisms, micromotors and magnetic heads for tape-recorders; liquid crystal displays for calculators and watches, and quartz crystals for watches. Some of these plans are already being implemented.

    While we should encourage key components to be manufactured in Singapore, we cannot expect to be entirely self-sufficient. The electronics industry is such that there are literally thousands of types of components. The United States and Japan, which have the largest electronics industries in the world, import electronic components. Hong Kong, which has the world's largest production of radios and radio components, imports some radio components from Singapore. That is the nature of the electronics industry.

RICE
(Price increases)


    7. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Finance (i) the reasons for the recent increase in the price of rice; and (ii) whether the price of rice will be further increased within the next six months.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, since June 1977, the export prices of Thai rice have been rising as a result of strong regional demand from Indonesia and Malaysia, a long and widespread drought which affected the rice harvest of Thailand, and measures taken by the Thai Board of Trade to control exports. As Singapore obtains more than 90% of her rice supplies from Thailand, we are directly affected by these developments. Thai 100% wholegrain (second grade) and Thai 10% broken, both Government Stockpile grades, are the common grades of rice consumed in Singapore. Their prices rose from US$280 FOB and US$238 FOB per metric ton, respectively, in June 1977 to reach US$390 and US$363 FOB per metric ton in February 1978.

    The sharp increases have forced us to raise the prices of Government Stockpile rice released to importers and cooperatives. For the Thai 100% second grade rice, an increase of $5 brought the price to $50 per picul (or 60.5 kg) in February 1978. For Thai 10% broken, the price was raised by $7 to $45 per picul in February 1978. With a reasonable trade mark-up, the retail price should be close to 56 cents per kati (or 605 grammes) for the Thai 100% second grade, and 51 cents per kati for the Thai 10% broken. Consumers can purchase their rice at these prices at the NTUC Welcome and other cooperative supermarkets, NTUC Welcome Fair Price Shops and consumer clubs.

    Like other commodities that we import for consumption, we must pay the market price for rice. The presence of a Government Rice Stockpile gives some degree of stability to price of rice in Singapore, but the price of Thai rice depends basically on production and market trends in Thailand. However, prices

Column: 737

will be maintained at the present levels as long as possible.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Ministry of Finance looking for alternative sources of supply of rice? Moreover, what has happened to the education programme to get people to eat other types of rice, say, from the United States and, at one time, West Pakistani rice?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the question of alternative sources of supply of rice has been looked into all the time by the Ministry. But there remains a strong preference for Thai rice by Singapore consumers. The education programme was carried out by the Ministry but the fact remains that most Singapore consumers still prefer Thai rice.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Mr Speaker, Sir, could the Senior Minister of State tell us why glutinous rice is difficult to come by, and whether it will be readily available, especially for the forthcoming Chinese festival? What is the Ministry planning to do about this?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, glutinous rice, like the other Thai rice, again depends on supply conditions in Thailand. There is a shortage of glutinous rice in Thailand and the Ministry is doing its utmost to negotiate for the supply into Singapore.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Mr Speaker, Sir, is it not true that the export of glutinous rice is now being banned by the Thai Government?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, that may be so. But again, as I have said earlier on, the Ministry is negotiating with the Thai Government for the supply of glutinous rice to Singapore.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Senior Minister of State tell us whether it will be possible for us to get an alternative supply from, say, Taiwan for instance?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, we can only look into that, but I cannot at this stage assure the Member that the supply will be forthcoming from Taiwan or other sources. But we in the Ministry will certainly look at other alternative sources of supply,

     Encik Sidek bin Saniff (Kolam Ayer): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head F be reduced by $10 in respect of item 3310 of Subhead Code FA-03 of the Main Estimates.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, one of the many satisfactions of a student is the completion of his studies in the final examinations, especially when the result is encouraging. I would consider that the greatest form of satisfaction is winning a scholarship, such as the President's scholarship which is awarded not only for excellent performance in academic subjects but also for an ability to grasp and practise education as a life-long process, which includes extracurricular activities. Parents will certainly be jubilant if their children could win scholarships. They too have to play a very important role in their children's performance. Most students have to go through hard work at the tertiary level, whether at home or abroad; they performed well.

    The pride borne out of success is not just the student's or the parent's but also of the state and of our society that nurture them. Our scholarship recipients today are an ideal model for all our aspiring youngsters. It is this strife for excellence that has been so characteristic of Singaporeans, especially in 1959, which has consequently made us commandingly skilful masters of our own destiny. In this respect, Sir, the State should be fortunate to get the service of these scholars after completion of their studies. In line with this belief, I would like to ask the Hon. Prime Minister whether all these scholars, this fortunate category, serve the State after the completion of their studies? Are they still in

Column: 740

the service now? To what extent has their contribution been positive to the State? Hopefully, good answers to these questions would become pointers that could inspire other students with the spirit of this scholarship.

    At the same time, I would also like to know why the allocation for this year is $13,500 less than last year.

     The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, the short answer is that in the years 1976 and 1977, the number of scholarships awarded under the category of President's scholarships was nine and five respectively, figures which are considerably lower than previous years which reached a high of 11 for 1972 and also 11 for 1973. This means that the amount needed to pay for the present first and second year President's scholars who will be in their second and third year next year will drop. I have a Table (Cols. 827-828) of these figures which I propose to include in my reply but which will make no sense if I read them out. Briefly, in June 1975, a new Chairman took over the PSC. Watching these figures, my conclusion is that the new Chairman has much higher standards. It is not necessarily a bad thing because if we maintain the prestige and the excellence of this particular scholarship, then the scholars must be those who are likely to do really well. Table - SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS

    The figures that would concern me more would be FA-03, subhead 3310, items (c) and (d). Item (c) Scholarships, fellowships and training courses overseas, shows an increase from $387,200 to $400,000. Item (d) Scholarships, fellowships and training courses for students in local institutions of higher learning, shows a decrease from $1,163,360 to $1,103,420.

    I cannot too strongly support the view of the Member for Kolam Ayer. It is one of the best investments we can make in our people. Unfortunately, at the age of 18-plus, it is not possible to have an accurate character profile. Therefore, a wastage of some 20% is unavoidable. Just taking the President's scholarships from 1966 to 1977, a total of

Column: 741

94 such scholarships was awarded. In fact, the total overseas scholarships range from 100 to 130 per annum. But for President's scholarships, it ranged from a high of 11 in 1972 and 1973 to a low of four in 1969 and a second low of five in 1977. Of these 94, 30 are still studying; 44 are in Government departments: two are lecturing in the Singapore Polytechnic and the University of Singapore; three are working in statutory boards; one is in Sembawang Shipyard; three have resigned from the Government Service; one has declined Government appointment and paid up the liquidated damages; two are nominal President's scholars; in other words, they have accepted the scholarship but not the rewards nor the obligation to serve the Government that goes with it; one failed in his studies and the award has been terminated; seven are still in national service.

    It is the intention of the Government, through the Public Service Commission which administers these awards fairly and impartially, to increase the number of scholarships, both for study abroad and at the University of Singapore and Nanyang University. The problem is, again, assessment. The present Chairman of the PSC would like to assess scholars after they have done their national service. In other words, assessment at 20-plus so that together with their scholastic achievement which is easily measurable, a fair profile of the man's stamina, perseverance, dependability and qualities of leadership, would have emerged from his interaction with his peers, his superiors and his subordinates in national service. We are still debating the pros and cons of this change which we know will be most unwelcome by the students themselves who feel that they can do their nine months national service before they go off to university and fill up in between during their vacations and when they return from graduation. It is a difficult decision to make. I have no doubt that if we do the assessment at 20-plus years, the wastage rate will go down. Unfortunately, I do have some doubts as to the value of holding back some 100-130 students every year for an extra two and a

Column: 742

half years in order to avoid the wastage. Even if the assessment was made at 20-plus years, I still do not believe we can eliminate the human error. The human being does not reveal himself in his fullness perhaps till 30-plus years in his motivations, convictions, steadfastness, qualities which are not necessarily measurable as you could measure intelligence, application, discipline; but these are qualities which are absolutely critical for total performance in human societies spread over a lifetime.

    The disadvantage also cannot be measured. The formative years of a man's or a young woman's life are in his or her late teens. That is the time when exposure to a new environment, a new society, the different norms, different modes of conduct in institutions of excellence overseas, stimulates ideas in an individual. We have found from those who have returned that those who have gone for postgraduate work have derived less from their stay overseas than those who have gone for their under-graduate work when they were in their late teens. So there is this trade off. Do we want to cut down on the wastage by holding them back till they are 20-plus? Do we run the risk of a high wastage of 20% and let them go off at 18-plus?

    But I can assure the Member for Kolam Ayer that this drop of $13,500 for President's scholarships does not reflect Government's policy. It reflects a much higher and more stringent standard of a Chairman who has himself been a scholar, a school master, a successful entrepreneur in the earth-moving business, in the construction business, in the shipbuilding business, and is therefore a fairly hard-headed and shrewd assessor of men in their totality, not just men as scholars, speakers or performers but men as people who am likely to make a contribution in life, not just to themselves and their families but to the society that has paid for their education and will make a special extra contribution for their special extra educational experience.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, on a point of elucidation. Just now the Hon. Prime Minister mentioned the number of scholar-

Column: 743

ship recipients. I take it that boys and girls are involved in this exercise. If the boys have to do 2 1/2 years' national service before they can be considered for the President's scholarships, then it would not be fair to them because the girls do not have to do national service and they will therefore have an advantage over the boys. I would be grateful if the Hon. Prime Minister can give an elucidation to the House on this point.

     The Prime Minister: Sir, I am not sure whether not doing national service is an advantage. It happens to be what is popularly believed by those who have to do national service - that those who have not done so have gained an advantage over them. Over the long haul, it is very doubtful if that is a sound proposition. As for the girls, yes there has been a shift from all male awards for overseas scholarships to an increasingly equal spread between the sexes. Two factors have determined this. Firstly, the attitude of parents who prefer to keep their daughters at home and at universities in Singapore and, secondly, also the change in the Chairmanship of the PSC. The new Chairman, partly because his daughters have gone overseas without mishap, takes a very different view of giving scholarships to young ladies to go overseas. I have every confidence that over a spread of another three to five years, the sex ratio may be more equal.
3.15 p.m.

    As for women not doing national service, I think that is not a permanent state of affairs. The drop in the number of additions per annum to the total population, the number of births per annum, from a high of 64,000 in 1958 went down to a low of 39,700 last year and the year before; I am not sure which one is lower. It means that we have to take the girls into national service to do many jobs which men are doing in order to keep up the Force's level; all the clerical work, all the signals work, all the jobs now done by storemen, jobs that do not need the extra physical
